resources.string: There are currently no tracked news stories.\nPress the button below to begin tracking a news story.
Enter URL of a news story to begin tracking
Only BBC News and BBC Sport articles are currently supported.
There are no tracked stories to manage.
How often to check for new updates:
Article is not suitable for tracking, please choose another article
No interests found. Begin tracking stories to register your interests!
You can track BBC News and BBC Sport articles. Support for new sources will be added in the future.
How do I begin tracking news stories?

Open a BBC article in your device\'s browser. Copy the URL of the page. Press the add new story button and paste the URL into the text field or press the \"Copy from Clipboard\" button. This format is accepted:
e.g. Ryan Lochte: Speedo and Ralph Lauren end sponsorship - http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-37159288
What are the words with the pink backgrounds?
These are topic words that work like tags for representing the main topic of a story. These get updated when you upvote or downvote an article in your timeline.
It shows how your news story progresses over time. Newer developments are on the top of the timeline. These updates are retrieved automatically.
How do I get new updates for my tracked stories?
You can either pull the My Tracked Stories screen down to manually refresh, or set an automatic background update frequency in the settings.
What are the entries on the My Tracked Stories screen?

Each entry is one of your tracked stories. A new one is created for each article you submit. The main text is the signature of the most recent article for that story. They are sorted from most to least recent.
This is a quick summary of an article. You can see each development\'s signature in the timeline.
What do the thumbs-up and thumbs-down buttons in the timeline do?

You can provide feedback on each automatically retrieved article. If an article fits exactly what you want to read about, you can give it a thumbs-up to upvote it. The topic words of that article get strengthed for the story and new articles in the future will attempt to be more about those topic words. It\'s similar for downvoting an article. More feedback equals more precise articles in the future.
This app is part of a project for King\'s College London, created by Violet Avkhukova.
Thanks to cheerio, natural, pos-js, and nlp-compromise for some of the backend functionality.
Thanks to Freepik at flaticon for the app logo.
You can send me feedback or bugs to my email (press here).
